report_title: Cigarette & Tobacco Products Wholesaling in the US
executive_summary: Revenue for the Cigarette and Tobacco Products Wholesaling industry has shrunk over the past five years as wholesalers have contended with expanding regulatory and economic challenges and shifts in consumer preferences. The rapidly growing popularity of e-cigarettes has prompted wholesalers to expand their product portfolios, partially offsetting cigarette and tobacco product declines. Despite plummeting smoking rates, e-cigarette usage kept sales steady amid the pandemic. Over the past five years, revenue for the Cigarette and Tobacco Products Wholesaling industry has declined at a CAGR of 1.0% to reach an estimated $149.2 billion in 2023. Inflationary pressures will prompt an estimated 1.6% in revenue in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: According to the CDC, e-cigarette unit sales expanded by 39.3% between February 2020 and October 2022. Flavored e-cigarettes have continued drawing younger, previously nonsmoking consumers in. Despite a substantial decline in the percentage of traditional cigarette smokers, cigarette and tobacco wholesalers saw a marginal increase in sales in 2020. Electronic vapor products are considered healthier than traditional tobacco products, boosting the popularity of the cigarette alternatives over the past five years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Regulatory Scrutiny Dampens Growth Prospects
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Regulators have recently cracked down on e-cigarettes, banning flavored cartridge-based e-cigarettes in 2020. Regulation surrounding traditional tobacco products has continued tightening, with federal and state excise taxes on tobacco increasing yearly for the past decade. Although federal excise taxes are remitted by tobacco manufacturers, wholesalers shoulder state excise taxes, forcing them to raise product prices. Federal antismoking campaigns, like The Real Cost, have weakened demand for traditional and electronic cigarettes through ads that highlight the adverse effects of smoking.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Inflationary Pressure Offsets the E-Cigarette Boom
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Ballooning cigarette prices have started to take a toll on consumers' budgets, especially amid unfavorable economic conditions. A drop in per capita disposable income and expanding inflation reduced demand for cigarettes and tobacco products in 2022. Rising unemployment and shrinking consumer confidence levels will continue mitigating cigarette and tobacco sales in 2023.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Heightened Competition Will Push Smaller Wholesalers Out
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Manufacturers' sales branches and offices (MSBOs) will continue to dominate wholesale operations while large-scale independent wholesalers will consolidate to cut costs. Smaller independent wholesalers will struggle to compete with established brands and wholesale giants and exit the industry. Still, a handful of new wholesalers will emerge to capitalize on the expanding demand for e-cigarettes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Wholesalers Will Contend With Plummeting Smoking Rates
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rising excise taxes and antismoking campaigns will continue to curb traditional smoking rates over the next five years. Regulators will crack down on e-cigarettes, which have created a new generation of nicotine users. As a negative social stigma surrounding e-cigarette usage expands, consumers will turn to substitutes like marijuana and nicotine replacement therapy. Health-conscious trends will contribute to declining demand for traditional tobacco products and e-cigarettes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Healthy Economy Will Slow Revenue Declines For Cigarette And Tobacco Wholesalers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Shrinking unemployment rates and expanding disposable income levels will spur demand for tobacco products despite their lofty prices. Inflated consumer spending will encourage consumers to purchase discretionary items, like cigarettes and tobacco products. Although the e-cigarette boom will stall, younger consumers will continue representing a vital market for the cigarette alternatives.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry acquire packaged cigarettes and other tobacco products from manufacturers and sell the goods to retailers such as convenience stores, supermarkets, specialized tobacco stores, street vendors or internet tobacco retailers. In addition, they may also sell to other wholesalers. The sales and distribution offices of tobacco product manufacturers are included in this industry.
key_trends: Competition between tobacco manufacturers with sales offices (MSBOs) and traditional merchant wholesalers varies. MSBOs benefit from brand loyalty, while merchant wholesalers must differentiate themselves via product range, quality and service.
Counterfeit and smuggled cigarettes are significant sources of external competition. Illegal market businesses offer lower prices since they don't comply with regulatory requirements.

The explosive popularity of e-cigarettes has mitigated broader declines for cigarette and tobacco wholesalers. E-cigarette campaigns, often geared toward younger consumers, fostered a new generation of nicotine users.
Expanding regulation will continue to curb smoking rates and cigarette sales. Excise taxes will continue rising and antismoking campaigns will increasingly focus on e-cigarettes.
Cigarette and tobacco product wholesalers focus on smokeless products as smoking rates dwindle. Frontrunner Altria purchased a 35.0% stake in e-cigarette company Juul in 2018
Wholesalers commit to limiting youth exposure to tobacco. Reynolds American announced its sponsorship of TruAge, an age verification system, in 2022.
Most assistance and regulation apply to upstream cigarette and tobacco manufacturers. Since many wholesalers are vertically integrated with manufacturers, policies trickle down to wholesalers.

Although excise taxes on tobacco products continue rising, demand for cigarettes persists. E-cigarettes aren't currently subject to a federal excise tax, prompting many smokers to switch to these vaping devices.

MSBOs have a considerably higher profit margin compared with merchant wholesalers. Despite expanding regulatory costs, vertically-integrated wholesalers have supported profit over the past five years.

An increase in federal excise taxes raises purchase costs for wholesalers. Tobacco manufacturers shoulder federal excise taxes on tobacco products, while state and local excise taxes are wholesalers' responsibility.
Cigarette and tobacco product wholesalers follow upstream manufacturers and downstream retailers. The Southeast's long history of tobacco cultivation has brought many wholesalers to the region.
As cigarette prices soar, wholesalers move to higher-income regions. States with higher levels of disposable income provide more downstream demand for wholesalers.
E-cigarettes are replacing traditional cigarettes as health consciousness expands. The electronic alternatives are considered to be slightly healthier than traditional cigarettes.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market includes standalone convenience stores and gas stations with convenience stores.

products_and_services.product_description: The visual appears to be a pie chart showing the percentage share of menthol cigarettes as 27.7% among the products and services offered.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Tobacco manufacturers are required to pay federal excise taxes under chapter 52 of the Internal Revenue Code. Excise taxes are passed down from manufacturer to wholesaler through higher purchase prices. States also levy their own taxes on tobacco products, further increasing per-unit prices and reducing demand.

business_locations.location_description: Thanks to the region's favorable climate and soil conditions, tobacco is a major crop in the Southeast. The region's long history with tobacco cultivation has brought more than half of the current cigarette and tobacco producers to the region.

Urban hubs and c-stores support cigarette demand in the Mid-Atlantic. New York contains the most convenience stores of any state, attracting wholesalers to the area. Major cities in the Mid-Atlantic (New York, Philadelphia, Boston) provide a substantial pool of customers for cigarette and tobacco wholesalers.

California leads cigarette and tobacco sales in the West. Higher disposable income levels in California support demand for cigarettes and tobacco products. The West's access to major transportation routes makes it easier for wholesalers to distribute cigarettes and tobacco products nationwide.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE US ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO TAX AND TRADE BUREAU (TTB)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The TTB ensures the collection of tobacco federal excise taxes and qualifies applicants for permits to import tobacco products or to operate tobacco export warehouses. The bureau performs tobacco inspections to verify an applicant's qualification information, check the security of the premises and ensure tax compliance.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, FIREARMS AND EXPLOSIVES (ATF)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The ATF investigates the trafficking of contraband tobacco products in violation of Federal law and sections of the Internal Revenue Code. As part of the ATF, the Prevent All Cigarette Trafficking (PACT) Act regulates the sale and shipment of cigarettes and tobacco products across state lines and requires wholesalers to register with the TTB and comply with certain reporting and record-keeping requirements.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE FEDERAL CIGARETTE LABELING AND ADVERTISING ACT (FCLAA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The FCLAA requires all cigarette packages and advertisements to include specific health warnings and statements about the dangers of smoking. Wholesalers must include one of four approved warning statements.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Manufacturers' sales branches and offices (MSBOs) are the most prominent cigarette and tobacco wholesalers. MSBOs are wholly owned distribution subsidiaries of tobacco product manufacturers. These integrated companies benefit from economies of scale and the cost efficiencies associated with integrating manufacturing and wholesaling operations.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Merchant Wholesalers Emerge To Capitalize On E-Cigarettes' Popularity
concentration_points.concentration_description: Aside from the two MSBOs in the Cigarette and Tobacco Products Wholesaling industry (Altria Group and Reynolds American), the remaining wholesalers are independent and smaller scale. Over the past five years, cigarette and tobacco wholesalers have expanded alongside demand for e-cigarettes. Most of these new wholesalers are small-scale and independent.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases remain flat despite upstream regulation
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are the largest expense for cigarette and tobacco wholesalers, which is typical of a wholesaling industry. Over the past five years, manufacturers have raised their unit prices to compensate for falling sales volumes and increased regulatory expenses. A decline in the world price of tobacco has offset price hikes, keeping purchase costs stable.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: State and local excise taxes boost other costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: State and local excise taxes are considered other costs for cigarette and tobacco wholesalers. State-level tax rates for a pack of cigarettes range from a low of $0.17 per pack in Missouri to a high of $5.01 in the District of Columbia.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Tobacco's Addictive Nature Keeps Sales Steady
volatility_points.volatility_description: Tobacco products have long been considered 'recession-proof' since their sales aren't significantly tied to short-term changes in economic conditions. Tobacco sales often expand during economic recessions as low consumer confidence and higher stress levels prompt consumers to turn to the alleviating effects of tobacco.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Popularity of E-Cigarettes Offsets Declines Associated With Health Consciousness
volatility_points.volatility_description: Just as the percentage of traditional cigarette smokers began declining, e-cigarettes hit the market.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: E-Cigarettes Lure Smokers Who Want to Quit
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: E-cigarettes work by heating a liquid (often containing nicotine) into an aerosol that can be inhaled instead of burning tobacco like traditional cigarettes. E-cigarettes are considered to be slightly less harmful than traditional cigarettes and have been marketed as a means for traditional smokers to quit.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in such a crowded industry?
FAQs.answer: Wholesale suppliers maintain a competitive edge by producing cigarettes on a large scale, thus cutting down on production costs per unit. Also, many company operators have formed a niche in certain product lines, like e-cigarettes and smokeless tobacco.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: While a healthy US economy benefits industry operators, demand for their products is generally able to withstand periods of poor economic performance because of brand loyalty and the addictive nature of nicotine (found in tobacco products).

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: The world price of tobacco (the industry's biggest input) is moderately volatile. However, this typically has little impact on industry operators, as they are generally able to pass the cost on to their customers.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: The Southeast region is the most popular region for industry operators. This largely has to do with the abundance of tobacco farms in the region and the ease of obtaining inputs for industry operators.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, like the capacity to manufacture electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes)?
FAQs.answer: Most major players in the industry are manufacturing at least one brand of e-cigarette, which plays a large part in keeping the industry afloat. Regulations have risen on this product segment, however, which has dampened some of its growth.

FAQs.question: Does your company use RFID to optimize inventory management and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: The introduction of inventory management technology has improved and allowed companies to realize efficiencies over the current period.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profit?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are subject to many regulations, including federal, state and local excise taxes, which have heavily impacted revenue and profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators receive assistance in dealing with the heavily regulated environment through industry associations, like the Tobacco Merchants Association and the Tobacco Vapor Electronic Cigarette Association.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit compare to your major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Margins vary significantly among the industry's major players. Typically, margins are higher for MSBOs than for merchant wholesalers.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit?
FAQs.answer: Industry profit is not strongly affected by input prices. Thus, while the world price of tobacco (the industry's key input) fluctuates, industry operators have endured, as price hikes are not a major deterrent for their customers.

FAQs.question: Are there any opportunities for mergers or acquisitions to boost your economies of scale? Do you always operate at peak processing capacity?
FAQs.answer: Achieving scale economies through investment in large warehouse facilities will maximize profitability if the wholesaler operates at peak volume processing capacity. This is critical in an industry with razor-thin gross profit.

FAQs.question: What warehousing and order processing technology do you use? Are there any available technologies that can improve your profit and productivity?
FAQs.answer: Automation - reduces costs, particularly those associated with labor. The ability to improve and invest in warehousing and order processing technology will likely reduce processing and labor costs while maximizing total volume sold.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to combat or prepare for evolving regulations? What less regulated product lines can you focus on?
FAQs.answer: Operators experience a comprehensive and increasingly tougher regulatory environment. The success of industry operators depends heavily on compliance with broad, comprehensive regulation of tobacco products, which can vary widely across state lines and different tobacco product types. Regulations have strengthened on certain product lines, mainly on e-cigarettes, which have advertised different flavors for their nicotine products.

FAQs.question: How does your company adapt during periods of low demand? What percentage of your revenue comes from noncigarette tobacco products?
FAQs.answer: In general, a reduction in the percentage of smokers leads to a lower sales volume of cigarettes, which may reduce industry revenue if per-unit prices are kept constant.

FAQs.question: In what ways has your company been affected by heightened levels of regulation? Are you able to pass on the negative effects of regulation increases?
FAQs.answer: Industry policy, with respect to the distribution of these products, affects issues like product packaging, restrictions on advertising and remittance of.
